summary: This document is an email from a prosecutor discussing sentencing guideline calculations for a defendant in the Epstein case. It details the application of U.S. Sentencing Guidelines for obstruction of an investigation into sex trafficking of minors, resulting in a stipulated range of 41-51 months' imprisonment. The email notes the defendant was considered significantly less culpable than Epstein and a minor participant.

persons.name: Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the primary figure in the underlying sex trafficking offense; the defendant is described as significantly less culpable than him.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the email discussing sentencing guideline calculations for a defendant charged with obstructing the investigation into Epstein's sex trafficking.

connections.description: The prosecutor is calculating sentencing for a defendant involved in obstructing the investigation into Epstein's crimes.

events.title: Applicable Guidelines Manual Edition
events.description: The November 1, 2006 edition of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines Manual applies to the offense charged.

keyFacts: The document calculates a sentencing guidelines range of 41 to 51 months' imprisonment for a defendant charged with obstructing the investigation into Epstein's sex trafficking of minors.
The underlying offense involved sex trafficking of minors with more than five minor victims, leading to a high base offense level.
The defendant received a 3-level reduction for being considered a 'minor participant' in the criminal activity, significantly lowering the sentencing range.
The prosecutor explicitly states the defendant was 'very significantly less culpable than Epstein'.
The calculation assumes the defendant will accept responsibility and plead guilty, allowing for further sentence reductions.
